title: TPAR Explained: What It Is and Who Must Lodge
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: If you work in certain industries and pay contractors to help run your business, thereâ€™s a yearly report you might need to complete - the Taxable Payments Annual Report (TPAR) (pronounced teeâ€‘par, if youâ€™re interested). It may sound technical, but itâ€™s actually quite straightforward. in this article will walk you through what TPAR is, who needs to lodge it, and how to do it with more confidence.
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

If you work in certain industries and pay contractors to help run your business, thereâ€™s a yearly report you might need to complete - the Taxable Payments Annual Report (TPAR) (pronounced teeâ€‘par, if youâ€™re interested). It may sound technical, but itâ€™s actually quite straightforward. This article explains what TPAR is, who needs to lodge it, and how to do it with fewer surprises.


Overview at a Glance


â€¢ TPAR â€“ Taxable Payments Annual Report: A yearly report to the ATO about payments you made to contractors in certain industries.

â€¢ Who needs it? Businesses that pay contractors in specific service categories (e.g., construction, cleaning, IT, freight).

â€¢ Deadline: 28 August for the last financial year that ended 30 June.

â€¢ What to include: Contractor details, total amounts paid (incl. GST).


What TPAR Means


The Taxable Payments Annual Report (TPAR) is a yearly report that some businesses have to submit to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). It shows how much you paid contractors for services during the financial year.

The ATO then cross-checks your reported payments with the contractorsâ€™ tax returns, helping to make sure everyone reports their income correctly - and keeping the tax system fair.


Who Should Lodge a TPAR?


You may need to lodge a TPAR if your business:

âœ” Has an Australian Business Number (ABN), and
âœ” Pays contractors to provide certain services. Industries commonly required to lodge include:

ğŸ— Building and construction
 ğŸ§¼ Cleaning services
 ğŸšš Courier and road freight
 ğŸ’» Information technology (IT)
 ğŸ›¡ Security, investigation, or surveillance

If your business provides both TPAR services and other unrelated services, work out what percentage of your income comes from the reportable services. If itâ€™s 10% or more, you have lodge a TPAR; if itâ€™s less than 10%, you generally donâ€™t need to.

Note: This 10% rule doesnâ€™t apply to businesses providing building and construction services as these businesses usually need to report regardless of the percentage.

Full list and examples are on the ATO website. Click here to learn more details.


When Is the Deadline?


28 August each year.

For example, for contractor payments made from 1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026, you have to lodge TPAR by 28 August 2026.


What to Include in a TPAR


Payerâ€™s details, include:

â€¢ Your details: Entity name, address and contact details

â€¢ Your ABN (Australian Business Number)

For each contractor, include:

â€¢ Personal details: Name, address and phone number

â€¢ ABN (Australian Business Number)

â€¢ Total amount you paid them, including GST

You can usually find this information on the invoices your contractors provide.

See a sample TPAR report here.


What to Leave Out of a TPAR


âŒ Employee wages - money you pay your staff is reported through payroll, not TPAR.

âŒ Materials only - if you just bought supplies and didnâ€™t pay for services, leave it out.

âŒ Incidental labour - small, one-off helper or demo work that isnâ€™t part of the main service.

âŒ Unpaid invoices after 30 June â€“ only include payments you actually made on or before 30 June.

âŒ Labour-hire workers - if a labour-hire firm provides the worker, the payment is reported by the firm, not you.

âŒ Payments to foreign residents for work in Australia â€“ most of these are reported through PAYG foreign resident withholding. Only include them in TPAR if they arenâ€™t covered by PAYG.

âŒ Contractors without an ABN - usually not reported in TPAR. If you withheld tax because they didnâ€™t provide an ABN, report it using the PAYG payment summary â€“ withholding where ABN not quoted instead.

âŒ Private or domestic projects - work done for personal projects (not your business) should not be included.


Practical tips to make TPAR easier


ğŸ“Œ Keep good records all year

Upload each contractorâ€™s invoice to the corresponding payment transaction in the ANNA app or ANNA Business Dashboard. Categorise the payment as â€œsub-contractorâ€ and add any notes you need - donâ€™t wait until June 30!
ğŸ’¡ If your business is registered for GST, make sure your GST settings are saved in the ANNA Business Dashboard so GST components on payments are recorded correctly.

ğŸ’¡You need to keep these records for at least 5 years starting from when you prepared or obtained the records or completed the transactions or acts those records relate to, whichever is later.

ğŸ“Œ Check ABNs before you pay

Itâ€™s much easier to confirm contractor details up front than correct them at the end of the year. You can check their ABN details via ABN lookup.

ğŸ“Œ Use the ATO TPAR worksheet

The ATO provides a TPAR worksheet to help you calculate and organise payments for each contractor. Use this guide to make sure nothing is missed.

title: PAYG Instalments: A Practical Guide for Small Business
author: Livia Lin
excerpt:
If you run a small businesses, work as a sole trader, or operate through a company, you might receive a letter from the ATO asking you to pay PAYG instalments. Many business owners are caught off guard when this letter arrives. You might wonder: â€œWhy do I suddenly owe the ATO money?â€
â€œDid I do something wrong?â€
â€œHow am I going to pay for this?â€ This unexpected payable can strain your cash flow if youâ€™re not prepared. The good news? PAYG instalments are not a punishment â€” theyâ€™re often a sign that your business is growing. Theyâ€™re designed to help you avoid a much larger tax bill later by spreading your payments across the year instead of paying everything at once. In in this article, weâ€™ll break down what PAYG instalments are, why they happen, and how to stay in control of your finances.

content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

If you run a small business, work as a sole trader, or operate through a company, you might receive a letter from the ATO asking you to pay PAYG instalments. Many business owners are caught off guard when this letter arrives. You might wonder: â€œWhy do I suddenly owe the ATO money?â€
â€œDid I do something wrong?â€
â€œHow am I going to pay for this?â€ This unexpected payable can strain your cash flow if youâ€™re not prepared. The upside is: PAYG instalments are not a punishment â€” theyâ€™re often a sign that your business is growing. Theyâ€™re designed to help you avoid a much larger tax bill later by spreading your payments across the year instead of paying everything at once. In this guide, weâ€™ll break down what PAYG instalments are, why they happen, and how to stay in control of your finances.


Overview at a Glance


â€¢ PAYG instalments are advance payments on your income tax

â€¢ Paying them is a legal obligation once the ATO issues an instalment notice

â€¢ What you pay is credited toward your final tax outcome

â€¢ The ATO usually enrols you automatically once your income reaches certain levels

â€¢ You can adjust the amount, but underpaying may lead to interest or penalties

Extra help: use ATOâ€™s PAYG instalment calculator to estimate your instalment amount.


What are PAYG instalments?


PAYG (Pay As You Go) instalments are regular payments you make during the year toward your expected income tax. Instead of paying one large tax bill at the end of the year, instalments spread the cost across the year, helping you manage cash flow.

Not every business has to pay PAYG instalments. The ATO usually places you in the system automatically if your income or last yearâ€™s tax payable meets certain thresholds.

Once the ATO issues an instalment notice, paying the amount by the due date is a legal requirement.

Even if you pay instalments, you still must lodge an annual tax return. Any instalments youâ€™ve paid are credited toward your total tax, so you either pay the remaining balance or receive a refund.


When the ATO adds you to PAYG instalments


After you lodge your tax return, the ATO reviews the information youâ€™ve reported to determine whether you should start paying PAYG instalments. One of the main things they consider is your instalment income, essentially your gross business and investment income. You can find the full list of what counts as instalment income on the ATO website.

For individuals or sole traders:

You will automatically enter the PAYG instalments system if you have all of the following:

â€¢ Instalment income from your latest tax return of $4,000 or more

â€¢ Tax payable on your latest notice of assessment of $1,000 or more

â€¢ Estimated (notional) tax of $500 or more

For companies:

Youâ€™ll automatically enter the PAYG instalments system if any of the following apply:

â€¢ Instalment income from latest tax return of $2 million or more

â€¢ Estimated (notional) tax of $500 or more

â€¢ The company is the head of a consolidated group

When youâ€™re entered into the system, the ATO will notify you â€“ usually through your myGov inbox, Online Services for business (i.e. ATO business portal), or by letter â€“ and tell you how often to pay and how to calculate your instalments.

Want to see a sample of PAYG instalment notice? Click here.


How often do you pay?


Most small businesses pay quarterly, but some eligible taxpayers can pay twice a year or annually, while very large businesses (with income over $20â€¯million) usually pay monthly.

Standard due dates for quarterly payers:

Sep Quarter - 1 July to 30 September: Due date: 28 October

Dec Quarter - 1 October to 31 December: Due date: 28 February

Mar Quarter - 1 January to 31 March: Due date: 28 April

Jun Quarter - 1 April to 30 June: Due date: 28 July

Make sure you pay all your instalments before you lodge your tax return. The instalments you pay throughout the year will then be taken into account in your tax assessment.

If you are already paying a quarterly BAS, your PAYG instalment will be added to your GST and other liabilities on the same activity statement, so you may pay everything in one go by the due date.

Want to know more about PAYG instalment payment cycles? Check out the ATO website.


How much do you should pay?


When it comes to PAYG instalment payments, you generally have two options:

Option 1 â€“ use the ATOâ€™s calculated amount
The ATO estimates your instalment based on your latest tax return, so you donâ€™t need to do any calculations.

Option 2 â€“ calculate using your instalment rate
The ATO provides an instalment rate (a percentage) that you multiply by your business income for the period. This method is useful if your income fluctuates during the year, as your instalments will rise and fall with your earnings.

If youâ€™re eligible to choose between these options, both will be shown on your activity statement or instalment notice. Choose your preferred option when you lodge, and youâ€™ll continue using that option for the rest of the financial year. If you want to change options, you may do so on your first activity statement of the next financial year.

Important: no matter which option you choose, it does not change your final tax liability. It simply spreads your tax payments throughout the year, helping you manage cash flow and avoid a large lump-sum bill.


Can you change the amount?


Yes, you may vary your PAYG instalment if you expect your income to be higher or lower than the ATO originally estimated. This helps keep your tax payments aligned with your real cash flow.

But timing matters â€“ you must make the variation on your activity statement or instalment notice before the due date for that instalment and before lodging your annual tax return for that year. After the due date passes, you generally canâ€™t adjust that period â€“ youâ€™ll need to wait until the next one.

Be careful when reducing payments. If your varied instalments end up being 15% or more below your actual tax liability, the ATO may charge interest on the shortfall.

More information about varying your PAYG instalments can be found on the ATO website.


PAYGI vs PAYGW: a common mix-up


The names are similar, so itâ€™s easy to confuse them but they apply to very different things:

PAYG instalments (PAYGI): these are advance payments towards your own income tax, helping you spread the cost across the year instead of paying a large amount at tax time.

PAYG withholding (PAYGW): this is tax you withhold from payments such as employee wages and remit to the ATO on their behalf.


Tips for managing PAYG instalments


Keep an eye on your profits: if your income changes during the year, review your instalments and vary them if needed so youâ€™re not over- or under-paying.

Read ATO notices carefully: PAYG instalments are a legal requirement. Your activity statement or instalment notice tells you how much to pay and when itâ€™s due.

Plan for cash flow: treat PAYG as part of your regular expenses. Setting funds aside as you earn can help you avoid surprises and stay in control of your finances.


How ANNA Money can help


ANNA Money is a business account designed to make financial admin simpler, especially for small businesses and sole traders.

With smart pots, you may set money aside specifically for tax obligations like PAYG instalments and GST, so funds are always ready when payments are due â€“ instead of getting mixed up with everyday spending. You can even set a percentage of your income to automatically transfer into your tax pot, helping you stay on top of cash flow and avoid lastâ€‘minute panic.

ANNA also provides a business summary (coming soon) and real-time tracking of your financial position, giving you a clear view of your income and expenses in one place. This makes it easier to estimate your PAYG instalments and plan your cash flow throughout the year.

content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

If most of your freelance or contracting income comes from your own effort, the ATO may classify it as PSI. Beatriceâ€™s journey as a UX designer shows how PSI works in real life and when the PSB tests can help you avoid PSI restrictions.

Ever wondered if your freelance gigs, design work, or side hustle might be caught under the ATOâ€™s Personal Services Income (PSI) rules? Youâ€™re not alone.

In Australia, if most of your income comes from your personal skills and effort, the ATO may classify it as PSI - not to trap you, but to make sure thereâ€™s fair tax treatment (especially when people use companies or trusts mainly to lower their tax).

Letâ€™s make this easy - and fun (well, more fun than it should be!) - to understand.

Weâ€™ll walk through a real-world story of Beatrice, a User Experience (UX) designer who starts as a sole trader, quickly expands her client base, and eventually operates a full design business through a company. Along the way, weâ€™ll see how her income gets defined as PSI, and how the PSB tests (Results, the 80% rule, Unrelated Clients, Employment, and Business Premises) apply at every stage.


Overview at a Glance:


What is PSI?
Income mainly from your own skills, effort, or expertise (over 50% of the value).

Who it affects:
Freelancers, contractors, consultants, creatives, specialists â€“ anyone paid for their personal effort.

Purpose of the PSI rules:
To stop income-splitting through structures like companies or trusts and to limit the deductions for employee-like contracting workers.

Business structure doesnâ€™t matter:
PSI rules apply whether youâ€™re a sole trader or have a company, trust, or partnership â€“ the incomeâ€™s still attributed to you.

How to avoid PSI restrictions: 
If you pass any of the Personal Services Business (PSB) tests (these are called: Results, the 80% rule, Unrelated Clients, Employment, and Business Premises), the PSI rules probably wonâ€™t apply to you.


Understanding PSI and PSB â€” before we dive into Beatriceâ€™s story


Before we get into Beatriceâ€™s journey, letâ€™s quickly look at two key ATO concepts: Personal Services Income (PSI) and Personal Services Business (PSB).

Personal Services Income (PSI) is income thatâ€™s mainly a reward for your own personal skills or effort. Itâ€™s common for freelancers, consultants, specialists and creatives - think designers, engineers, consultants, and contractors who get paid for the work they personally do. The PSI rules donâ€™t affect you if you're an employee receiving only salary or wages.

If you earn PSI, special tax rules apply to prevent you from â€œsplittingâ€ that income through a company, trust, or partnership to reduce tax. In other words, the ATO will generally attribute that income back to you, the person who did the work, and the deductions you may claim against this income are limited too.

However, you may qualify as a Personal Services Business (PSB) if you meet certain tests. If you do, the PSI rules wonâ€™t apply, and you may treat your income more like business income.

Here are the four PSB tests the ATO uses:

Results test - To pass this test, you should meet all 3 of the following conditions for at least 75% of your PSI you earned:

â€¢ Youâ€™re paid to produce a result.

â€¢ You use your own tools/equipment, and

â€¢ Youâ€™re responsible for fixing mistakes.

Unrelated clients test - You get income from two or more unrelated clients (and their associates).

Employment test - You hire others (employees or contractors) to do at least 20% of the principal work.

Business premises test - You keep business premises that are separate from your home and clientsâ€™ premises.

You can self-assess as a Personal Services Business (PSB) if either:

â€¢ You pass the Results test for most of your PSI (at least 75%), or

â€¢ You pass one of the other PSB tests and no single client (or their related associates) provides more than 80% of your PSI.

If you mayâ€™t self-assess as a PSB, you may be able to apply for a PSB determination (PSBD) from the ATO.


What to Do If the PSI Rules Donâ€™t Apply


Even if the PSI rules donâ€™t apply to your income, you still need to declare all your Personal Services Income (PSI) on your tax return. This means reporting your earnings just like any other business or personal income. When the rules donâ€™t apply, you may generally claim the full range of deductions that relate to earning the income, without the limitations that usually apply under the PSI rules.


What to Do If the PSI Rules Do Apply


If the PSI rules apply to you, youâ€™ve got to follow steps to comply with the ATOâ€™s requirements. First, attribute the PSI to the person who performed the work - thatâ€™s usually you - even if the income was paid to a company, trust, or partnership. Next, calculate your net PSI by deducting only the expenses allowed under the PSI rules, which are generally limited to those an employee could claim.

You may also have additional PAYG withholding or instalment obligations if the PSI received by your business wasnâ€™t promptly paid as salary or wages to the person doing the work. â€œPromptly paidâ€ means paying the amount by the 14th day after the relevant PAYG payment period in which the PSI was received.

Navigating the PSI rules can feel very tricky, but the ATOâ€™s got plenty of detailed guidance if you need it.

Next, we follow Beatriceâ€™s story to see how the rules play out in real life - and what it means for her taxes along the way.


Beatriceâ€™s Journey: UX Designer Turned Business Owner



Stage 1: From Employee to Sole Trader (2023)


Beatrice used to work as a UX designer for a software company X Pty Ltd, creating user workflows and interfaces. She wanted more control over her projects, so she became a sole trader, contracting back to the same company. She provides design services exclusively for X Pty Ltd, working in her home office (a spare bedroom) and using a combination of her own laptop and the companyâ€™s software subscriptions. Beatriceâ€™s paid hourly, has to fix errors when requested, and adjusts her designs according to the companyâ€™s feedback.


PSI and PSB Considerations


Results test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
To pass the Results test, three conditions have to be met:

â€¢ Paid to produce a specific result.

â€¢ Required to provide her own equipment or tools.

â€¢ Liable to fix mistakes at her own cost.

Beatrice doesnâ€™t meet the first two conditions: sheâ€™s paid by the hour, not for a specific deliverable, and she relies on X Pty Ltdâ€™s software subscriptions rather than fully supplying her own tools. While she fixes mistakes and uses her laptop, her liabilityâ€™s limited, as she isnâ€™t responsible for the cost of software subscriptions or other business overheads.

That means Beatrice canâ€™t self-assess as a Personal Services Business (PSB) under the Results test.

Additionally, since all of her PSI comes from a single client (X Pty Ltd), she canâ€™t rely on the other PSB tests (Unrelated Clients, Employment, Business Premises) to qualify. Sheâ€™ll need to report this income on her personal tax return as PSI income, and only limited deductions - directly related to earning the PSI - are allowed.

Other considerations: She needs to register for GST if turnover hits $75,000.


Stage 2: Growing Clients and Setting Up a Company (2024)


Beatriceâ€™s freelance work is picking up. Sheâ€™s recently secured a second client, Y Pty Ltd, referred by X Pty Ltd. Both businesses engage her for UX design services. She still works hourly from her home office using her own laptop, although she still relies on her clientsâ€™ software subscriptions to complete design tasks.

Encouraged by her growing workload - and hearing that â€œsetting up a company can save taxâ€ â€” Beatrice registers Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd. She plans to pay herself a salary and bring her partner, Henry, on board to help with administration, handling invoicing, emails, and client calls while she focuses on design work.

Over the year, the company earns (GST excl.):

â€¢ $100,000 from X Pty Ltd (59% of total income)

â€¢ $70,000 from Y Pty Ltd (41% of total income)

Total Income: $170,000

Beatrice paid herself $50,000 in wages to cover living expenses and reported $6,800 in PAYGW (tax withheld on wages) via the company's quarterly BAS (Business Activity Statement). No other business expenses have occurred. At the end of the financial year, she plans to pay Henry wages to make use of his tax-free threshold and reduce their overall tax position. Before going ahead, she consults an accountant - only to be shocked by the impact of PSI rules.


PSI and PSB Considerations


Results test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
Beatriceâ€™s still paid by the hour rather than for a specific result. She uses her own laptop, but she relies on client subscriptions for design tools and isnâ€™t fully responsible for business overheads. Therefore, she fails the Results test.

80% rule â€“ Beatrice passes âœ…
With multiple clients and no single client providing more than 80% of her PSI, she can consider other PSB tests (Unrelated Clients, Employment, and Business Premises) to see if she can qualify as a Personal Services Business (PSB) to avoid PSI rules.

Unrelated clients test - Beatrice fails âŒ
To pass this test, Beatrice must:

â€¢ Receive PSI from two or more unrelated clients, and

â€¢ Be engaged as a direct result of offering her services to the public.

Although Beatrice now works for two unrelated clients, both came through a referral - not from a public advertisement or tender. According to the ATO, â€œword-of-mouth referrals alone do not meet this testâ€ unless youâ€™re in a highly specialised niche industry. Because of this, her incomeâ€™s likely to fail this test.

Employment test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
Your business must employ or contract others to do at least 20% of the principal work that generates your PSI. Henryâ€™s work is administrative, not work that generates PSI.

Business premises test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
Beatrice continues to work from her home office, not separate business premises.


Tax implications


Beatrice has failed to establish her business as a PSB. This means the net PSI earned through Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd will still be attributed back to her personally. Deductions are limited under PSI rules, and the salary and super she plans to pay Henry canâ€™t be claimed.

Hereâ€™s how this works in practice: Beatrice calculates her net PSI: $170,000 income minus $50,000 salary = $120,000 net PSI.
She has to lodge both a personal income tax return and a company tax return.

In her Personal Tax Return, Beatrice reports:

â€¢ Salary: $50,000 with $6,800 tax withheld under â€˜Salary or wagesâ€™

â€¢ Attributed PSI: $120,000 under â€˜Attributed Personal Services Incomeâ€™

â€¢ Additional PAYGW obligations on $120,000 (explained below)

A note on deduction limitation:
Beatrice canâ€™t claim deductions for:

â€¢ Any salaries or super she plans to pay Henry canâ€™t be deducted under PSI rules, because his work is administrative, not principal work generating PSI. That means it doesnâ€™t reduce the attributed PSI or PAYGW obligations. Even if Beatrice pays Henry, these payments canâ€™t reduce her PSI or PAYG obligations. Henryâ€™s salary wonâ€™t be included in his assessable income, and any PAYG withholding Beatrice pays for him can be credited to her on her personal return to avoid double taxation.

â€¢ Home office occupancy costs such as rent, mortgage interest, rates, and land tax, to the extent they relate to her home office.


How Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd Reports PSI


The company reports the $120,000 of attributed PSI as a reconciliation item under â€œOther income not included in assessable incomeâ€. This excludes it from the companyâ€™s assessable income, and the PSI sectionâ€™s completed accordingly. This makes sure it complies with PSI rules while avoiding double taxation.


Interaction with Superannuation Guarantee (SG)


According to ATO ID 2015/9, when a company earns PSI and the incomeâ€™s merely attributed to the worker (not actually paid as wages), SG obligations donâ€™t generally arise. SG only applies when the worker actually receives wages or salary.

In Beatriceâ€™s case:

â€¢ She paid herself $50,000 in wages during the year. Because these are actual payments, SG obligations apply in this case. Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd needs to calculate and pay SG contributions for her.

The superannuation contributions are generally deductible and can reduce net PSI, provided the payments are made on time and meet the requirements under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

If Beatrice hadnâ€™t paid herself any wages and simply attributed the $170,000 back at year-end, no SG would be triggered, because no actual payment was made for principal work.


PAYGW Obligations


When your business earns Personal Services Income (PSI) and the PSI rules apply, the income has to be declared by the person who actually did the work - in Beatriceâ€™s case, thatâ€™s her. This affects how PAYG withholding (PAYGW) works, depending on whether the incomeâ€™s actually paid as salary or remains as â€œattributed PSI.â€

A. Salary Paid Promptly (under 14 days after PAYG period)
Beatriceâ€™s $50,000 salary was paid promptly, triggering normal PAYGW obligations. Her company correctly reported $6,800 via STP/BAS.

B. Attributed PSI (Not Paid Promptly)
The remaining $120,000 is treated as attributed PSI. Even though Beatrice didnâ€™t receive it as wages, the company still needs to:

â€¢ Calculate additional PAYGW on this $120,000 based on her marginal tax rate

â€¢ Report and pay the additional PAYGW through amended BAS for each quarter

â€¢ Provide Beatrice with an annual PAYG payment summary/income statement showing both salary with normal tax withheld and additional PAYGW

â€¢ Submit an annual report to the ATO at year-end, showing additional PAYG withholding at the end of the income year


Stage 3: Expanding Through Advertising (2025)


Beatrice continues to grow her business and consults an accountant about PSI rules. She places ads on LinkedIn and Facebook and creates a website showcasing her work. She gets two new clients, Z Pty Ltd and A Pty Ltd. Sheâ€™s still paid hourly for her UX design services and now fully relies on her own laptop, software subscriptions, and design tools.

To maintain efficient operations, Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd continues running smoothly. Henry supports administrative tasks, including invoicing, emails, and client calls.

Financial Year Overview:

Income (excl. GST):

â€¢ $100,000 from X Pty Ltd (46% of PSI)

â€¢ $70,000 from Y Pty Ltd (32% of PSI)

â€¢ $25,000 from Z Pty Ltd (11% of PSI)

â€¢ $25,000 from A Pty Ltd (11% of PSI)

Total Income: $220,000

Expenses (excl. GST):

â€¢ $45,000 salary to Beatrice (+$5,400 super)

â€¢ $45,000 salary to Henry (+$5,400 super)

â€¢ $2,000 accounting fees

â€¢ $1,000 software subscriptions

â€¢ $329 ASIC fee

Total Expense: $104,129


PSI and PSB Considerations:


Results test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ

Beatriceâ€™s still paid hourly, not for a specific outcome.

80% rule - Beatrice passes âœ…
With plenty of clients and no single client providing more than 80% of her PSI, she passes the 80% rule and can consider other PSB tests.

Unrelated clients test - Beatrice passes âœ…
Beatrice gained Z Pty Ltd and A Pty Ltd through public advertising, satisfying the â€œoffer to the publicâ€ requirement. Also, clients X, Y, Z and A are unrelated and not associated with each other, meaning the unrelated clients test is met.

Employment test - Beatrice fails âŒ 
Beatrice does all principal work herself; Henry only handles administrative tasks.

Business premises test - Beatrice fails âŒ 
Beatrice works from home without separate business premises.


Tax Implications


Beatriceâ€™s PSI now passes both the 80% rule and the unrelated clients test, which means she can self-assess as a Personal Services Business (PSB). As a result, the PSI rules no longer apply to her income.

This has several practical effects:

â€¢ Income Reporting: The income remains assessable at the company level and has to be reported under the relevant label in the company tax return. The resulting net profit is then taxed at the company tax rate of 25%.

â€¢ Deductions: Beatrice can claim a broader range of business expenses, including software subscriptions, ASIC fees, accounting fees, salaries and super to herself and Henry, and home-based business expenses (both running costs and occupancy costs). Sheâ€™s no longer restricted by PSI-specific deduction limits.

â€¢ Payroll Compliance: Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd must register for PAYG withholding (PAYGW) and report wages and PAYGW through its BAS. Pay runs should be completed using STP-enabled payroll software. The Superannuation Guarantee (SG) obligationâ€™s also triggered, and the company must pay SG on time to avoid penalty interest and disallowance of superannuation deductions.


Practical tips to avoid the PSI rules


1. Aim to pass the Results test â€“ get paid for outcomes, not hours
Structure contracts so youâ€™re engaged to deliver a specific result (fixed price, milestones, completion deliverables), supply key tools/equipment where it makes sense, and accept liability to fix defects at your cost. If all three apply for most (thatâ€™s over 75%) of your PSI, youâ€™re in the best position to show youâ€™re running a business, not just selling time.

Practical moves: switch hourly billing to fixed-price or milestone fees; add deliverable and warranty clauses; show you provide core equipment/software (or why it isnâ€™t needed).

2. Build a real client base - meet the Unrelated Clients test properly
Having more than one client isnâ€™t enough. The ATO wants to see that clients came from you offering services to the public (not just word-of-mouth). Think visible, traceable marketing that directly leads to work.
Practical moves: advertise; keep records linking enquiries to ads or listings; use public proposals/tenders; save website/LinkedIn evidence and client emails showing how they found you.

3. Consider the Employment test - get others to do principal work
If at least 20% (by value) of the principal work is done by people you employ or contract (and you meet the 80% rule), you may pass this test. Admin support doesnâ€™t count â€“ it has to be core service delivery.
Practical moves: document tasks and timesheets showing who did what; use contracts with subcontractors/employees who produce deliverables, not just admin.

4. Get proper, separate business premises if itâ€™s possible
To pass the Business Premises test, your premises must be separate from home and client sites and mainly used for your business.
Practical moves: lease or sublet a small studio, office, or exclusive long-term coworking desk; keep lease agreements and utility bills showing business use.

5. Keep client income under the 80% threshold (or apply for a PSBD)
If 80%+ of your PSI comes from one client (and associates), your options to rely on other PSB tests are restricted. Diversifying helps â€“ if you genuinely canâ€™t, a PSB Determination (PSBD) might be an option.
Practical moves: track income by client and their associates; plan marketing to reduce reliance on a single client; if youâ€™re stuck with one, consider applying for a PSBD with solid evidence.

6. Document everything - the ATO wants evidence, not claims
Good records often decide PSI outcomes. The ATO looks at how you got work, who did it, the terms, and how costs were allocated.
Practical moves: keep contracts, proposals, emails, invoices, marketing screenshots, timesheets, employee/contractor agreements and proof of payment.

7. Use the ATO tools - decision tool and PSB determination
Before you restructure or rely on PSB status, use the ATOâ€™s PSI decision tool and, if needed, the PSB determination process.
Practical moves: run the online PSI decision tool and save the output; if youâ€™re borderline, apply for a PSBD.

8. Donâ€™t treat the company as a tax-avoidance device
The PSI rules are antiâ€“income splitting. You canâ€™t just push PSI through a company or family members and expect to claim extra deductions, especially for non-principal work.
Practical moves: only pay associates for genuine, market-value services that contribute to principal work; keep clear role descriptions and timesheets.

9. If you mayâ€™t meet the tests, manage PSI compliance proactively
If PSI rules will apply, plan for them rather than hoping they donâ€™t: attribute PSI correctly, stick to allowed (employee-style) deductions, and manage PAYG and cashflow.
Practical moves: talk to an accountant early; separate PSI from non-PSI income in your records; budget for extra PAYG and tax.

10. Get professional advice and re-test each year
The ATOâ€™s guidance and your circumstances change over time, and PSI tests are applied each income year.
Practical moves: get a registered tax agent or adviser to review your setup annually and re-run the decision tool each year.

PSI and PSB Considerations


Results test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
To pass the Results test, three conditions have to be met:

â€¢ Paid to produce a specific result.

â€¢ Required to provide her own equipment or tools.

â€¢ Liable to fix mistakes at her own cost.

Beatrice doesnâ€™t meet the first two conditions: sheâ€™s paid by the hour, not for a specific deliverable, and she relies on X Pty Ltdâ€™s software subscriptions rather than fully supplying her own tools. While she fixes mistakes and uses her laptop, her liabilityâ€™s limited, as she isnâ€™t responsible for the cost of software subscriptions or other business overheads.

That means Beatrice canâ€™t self-assess as a Personal Services Business (PSB) under the Results test.

Additionally, since all of her PSI comes from a single client (X Pty Ltd), she canâ€™t rely on the other PSB tests (Unrelated Clients, Employment, Business Premises) to qualify. Sheâ€™ll need to report this income on her personal tax return as PSI income, and only limited deductions - directly related to earning the PSI - are allowed.

Other considerations: She needs to register for GST if turnover hits $75,000.


Stage 2: Growing Clients and Setting Up a Company (2024)


Beatriceâ€™s freelance work is picking up. Sheâ€™s recently secured a second client, Y Pty Ltd, referred by X Pty Ltd. Both businesses engage her for UX design services. She still works hourly from her home office using her own laptop, although she still relies on her clientsâ€™ software subscriptions to complete design tasks.

Encouraged by her growing workload - and hearing that â€œsetting up a company can save taxâ€ â€” Beatrice registers Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd. She plans to pay herself a salary and bring her partner, Henry, on board to help with administration, handling invoicing, emails, and client calls while she focuses on design work.

Over the year, the company earns (GST excl.):

â€¢ $100,000 from X Pty Ltd (59% of total income)

â€¢ $70,000 from Y Pty Ltd (41% of total income)

Total Income: $170,000

Beatrice paid herself $50,000 in wages to cover living expenses and reported $6,800 in PAYGW (tax withheld on wages) via the company's quarterly BAS (Business Activity Statement). No other business expenses have occurred. At the end of the financial year, she plans to pay Henry wages to make use of his tax-free threshold and reduce their overall tax position. Before going ahead, she consults an accountant - only to be shocked by the impact of PSI rules.


PSI and PSB Considerations


Results test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
Beatriceâ€™s still paid by the hour rather than for a specific result. She uses her own laptop, but she relies on client subscriptions for design tools and isnâ€™t fully responsible for business overheads. Therefore, she fails the Results test.

80% rule â€“ Beatrice passes âœ…
With multiple clients and no single client providing more than 80% of her PSI, she can consider other PSB tests (Unrelated Clients, Employment, and Business Premises) to see if she can qualify as a Personal Services Business (PSB) to avoid PSI rules.

Unrelated clients test - Beatrice fails âŒ
To pass this test, Beatrice must:

â€¢ Receive PSI from two or more unrelated clients, and

â€¢ Be engaged as a direct result of offering her services to the public.

Although Beatrice now works for two unrelated clients, both came through a referral - not from a public advertisement or tender. According to the ATO, â€œword-of-mouth referrals alone do not meet this testâ€ unless youâ€™re in a highly specialised niche industry. Because of this, her incomeâ€™s likely to fail this test.

Employment test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
Your business must employ or contract others to do at least 20% of the principal work that generates your PSI. Henryâ€™s work is administrative, not work that generates PSI.

Business premises test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ
Beatrice continues to work from her home office, not separate business premises.


Tax implications


Beatrice has failed to establish her business as a PSB. This means the net PSI earned through Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd will still be attributed back to her personally. Deductions are limited under PSI rules, and the salary and super she plans to pay Henry canâ€™t be claimed.

Hereâ€™s how this works in practice: Beatrice calculates her net PSI: $170,000 income minus $50,000 salary = $120,000 net PSI.
She has to lodge both a personal income tax return and a company tax return.

In her Personal Tax Return, Beatrice reports:

â€¢ Salary: $50,000 with $6,800 tax withheld under â€˜Salary or wagesâ€™

â€¢ Attributed PSI: $120,000 under â€˜Attributed Personal Services Incomeâ€™

â€¢ Additional PAYGW obligations on $120,000 (explained below)

A note on deduction limitation:
Beatrice canâ€™t claim deductions for:

â€¢ Any salaries or super she plans to pay Henry canâ€™t be deducted under PSI rules, because his work is administrative, not principal work generating PSI. That means it doesnâ€™t reduce the attributed PSI or PAYGW obligations. Even if Beatrice pays Henry, these payments canâ€™t reduce her PSI or PAYG obligations. Henryâ€™s salary wonâ€™t be included in his assessable income, and any PAYG withholding Beatrice pays for him can be credited to her on her personal return to avoid double taxation.

â€¢ Home office occupancy costs such as rent, mortgage interest, rates, and land tax, to the extent they relate to her home office.


How Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd Reports PSI


The company reports the $120,000 of attributed PSI as a reconciliation item under â€œOther income not included in assessable incomeâ€. This excludes it from the companyâ€™s assessable income, and the PSI sectionâ€™s completed accordingly. This makes sure it complies with PSI rules while avoiding double taxation.


Interaction with Superannuation Guarantee (SG)


According to ATO ID 2015/9, when a company earns PSI and the incomeâ€™s merely attributed to the worker (not actually paid as wages), SG obligations donâ€™t generally arise. SG only applies when the worker actually receives wages or salary.

In Beatriceâ€™s case:

â€¢ She paid herself $50,000 in wages during the year. Because these are actual payments, SG obligations apply in this case. Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd needs to calculate and pay SG contributions for her.

The superannuation contributions are generally deductible and can reduce net PSI, provided the payments are made on time and meet the requirements under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

If Beatrice hadnâ€™t paid herself any wages and simply attributed the $170,000 back at year-end, no SG would be triggered, because no actual payment was made for principal work.


PAYGW Obligations


When your business earns Personal Services Income (PSI) and the PSI rules apply, the income has to be declared by the person who actually did the work - in Beatriceâ€™s case, thatâ€™s her. This affects how PAYG withholding (PAYGW) works, depending on whether the incomeâ€™s actually paid as salary or remains as â€œattributed PSI.â€

A. Salary Paid Promptly (under 14 days after PAYG period)
Beatriceâ€™s $50,000 salary was paid promptly, triggering normal PAYGW obligations. Her company correctly reported $6,800 via STP/BAS.

B. Attributed PSI (Not Paid Promptly)
The remaining $120,000 is treated as attributed PSI. Even though Beatrice didnâ€™t receive it as wages, the company still needs to:

â€¢ Calculate additional PAYGW on this $120,000 based on her marginal tax rate

â€¢ Report and pay the additional PAYGW through amended BAS for each quarter

â€¢ Provide Beatrice with an annual PAYG payment summary/income statement showing both salary with normal tax withheld and additional PAYGW

â€¢ Submit an annual report to the ATO at year-end, showing additional PAYG withholding at the end of the income year


Stage 3: Expanding Through Advertising (2025)


Beatrice continues to grow her business and consults an accountant about PSI rules. She places ads on LinkedIn and Facebook and creates a website showcasing her work. She gets two new clients, Z Pty Ltd and A Pty Ltd. Sheâ€™s still paid hourly for her UX design services and now fully relies on her own laptop, software subscriptions, and design tools.

To maintain efficient operations, Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd continues running smoothly. Henry supports administrative tasks, including invoicing, emails, and client calls.

Financial Year Overview:

Income (excl. GST):

â€¢ $100,000 from X Pty Ltd (46% of PSI)

â€¢ $70,000 from Y Pty Ltd (32% of PSI)

â€¢ $25,000 from Z Pty Ltd (11% of PSI)

â€¢ $25,000 from A Pty Ltd (11% of PSI)

Total Income: $220,000

Expenses (excl. GST):

â€¢ $45,000 salary to Beatrice (+$5,400 super)

â€¢ $45,000 salary to Henry (+$5,400 super)

â€¢ $2,000 accounting fees

â€¢ $1,000 software subscriptions

â€¢ $329 ASIC fee

Total Expense: $104,129


PSI and PSB Considerations:


Results test â€“ Beatrice fails âŒ

Beatriceâ€™s still paid hourly, not for a specific outcome.

80% rule - Beatrice passes âœ…
With plenty of clients and no single client providing more than 80% of her PSI, she passes the 80% rule and can consider other PSB tests.

Unrelated clients test - Beatrice passes âœ…
Beatrice gained Z Pty Ltd and A Pty Ltd through public advertising, satisfying the â€œoffer to the publicâ€ requirement. Also, clients X, Y, Z and A are unrelated and not associated with each other, meaning the unrelated clients test is met.

Employment test - Beatrice fails âŒ 
Beatrice does all principal work herself; Henry only handles administrative tasks.

Business premises test - Beatrice fails âŒ 
Beatrice works from home without separate business premises.


Tax Implications


Beatriceâ€™s PSI now passes both the 80% rule and the unrelated clients test, which means she can self-assess as a Personal Services Business (PSB). As a result, the PSI rules no longer apply to her income.

This has several practical effects:

â€¢ Income Reporting: The income remains assessable at the company level and has to be reported under the relevant label in the company tax return. The resulting net profit is then taxed at the company tax rate of 25%.

â€¢ Deductions: Beatrice can claim a broader range of business expenses, including software subscriptions, ASIC fees, accounting fees, salaries and super to herself and Henry, and home-based business expenses (both running costs and occupancy costs). Sheâ€™s no longer restricted by PSI-specific deduction limits.

â€¢ Payroll Compliance: Beatrice Designs Pty Ltd must register for PAYG withholding (PAYGW) and report wages and PAYGW through its BAS. Pay runs should be completed using STP-enabled payroll software. The Superannuation Guarantee (SG) obligationâ€™s also triggered, and the company must pay SG on time to avoid penalty interest and disallowance of superannuation deductions.


Practical tips to avoid the PSI rules


1. Aim to pass the Results test â€“ get paid for outcomes, not hours
Structure contracts so youâ€™re engaged to deliver a specific result (fixed price, milestones, completion deliverables), supply key tools/equipment where it makes sense, and accept liability to fix defects at your cost. If all three apply for most (thatâ€™s over 75%) of your PSI, youâ€™re in the best position to show youâ€™re running a business, not just selling time.

Practical moves: switch hourly billing to fixed-price or milestone fees; add deliverable and warranty clauses; show you provide core equipment/software (or why it isnâ€™t needed).

2. Build a real client base - meet the Unrelated Clients test properly
Having more than one client isnâ€™t enough. The ATO wants to see that clients came from you offering services to the public (not just word-of-mouth). Think visible, traceable marketing that directly leads to work.
Practical moves: advertise; keep records linking enquiries to ads or listings; use public proposals/tenders; save website/LinkedIn evidence and client emails showing how they found you.

3. Consider the Employment test - get others to do principal work
If at least 20% (by value) of the principal work is done by people you employ or contract (and you meet the 80% rule), you may pass this test. Admin support doesnâ€™t count â€“ it has to be core service delivery.
Practical moves: document tasks and timesheets showing who did what; use contracts with subcontractors/employees who produce deliverables, not just admin.

4. Get proper, separate business premises if itâ€™s possible
To pass the Business Premises test, your premises must be separate from home and client sites and mainly used for your business.
Practical moves: lease or sublet a small studio, office, or exclusive long-term coworking desk; keep lease agreements and utility bills showing business use.

5. Keep client income under the 80% threshold (or apply for a PSBD)
If 80%+ of your PSI comes from one client (and associates), your options to rely on other PSB tests are restricted. Diversifying helps â€“ if you genuinely canâ€™t, a PSB Determination (PSBD) might be an option.
Practical moves: track income by client and their associates; plan marketing to reduce reliance on a single client; if youâ€™re stuck with one, consider applying for a PSBD with solid evidence.

6. Document everything - the ATO wants evidence, not claims
Good records often decide PSI outcomes. The ATO looks at how you got work, who did it, the terms, and how costs were allocated.
Practical moves: keep contracts, proposals, emails, invoices, marketing screenshots, timesheets, employee/contractor agreements and proof of payment.

7. Use the ATO tools - decision tool and PSB determination
Before you restructure or rely on PSB status, use the ATOâ€™s PSI decision tool and, if needed, the PSB determination process.
Practical moves: run the online PSI decision tool and save the output; if youâ€™re borderline, apply for a PSBD.

8. Donâ€™t treat the company as a tax-avoidance device
The PSI rules are antiâ€“income splitting. You canâ€™t just push PSI through a company or family members and expect to claim extra deductions, especially for non-principal work.
Practical moves: only pay associates for genuine, market-value services that contribute to principal work; keep clear role descriptions and timesheets.

9. If you canâ€™t meet the tests, manage PSI compliance proactively
If PSI rules will apply, plan for them rather than hoping they donâ€™t: attribute PSI correctly, stick to allowed (employee-style) deductions, and manage PAYG and cashflow.
Practical moves: talk to an accountant early; separate PSI from non-PSI income in your records; budget for extra PAYG and tax.

10. Get professional advice and re-test each year
The ATOâ€™s guidance and your circumstances change over time, and PSI tests are applied each income year.
Practical moves: get a registered tax agent or adviser to review your setup annually and re-run the decision tool each year.

title: How to Pay Yourself from a Company (Without Tax Surprises)
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: You run a company and youâ€™ve doing well. Now you want to take some money out of your company for yourself. Hooray! But before you rush off to do it, have a think about how you want to pay yourself, because doing it the wrong way can trigger big tax headaches. Hereâ€™s a practical guide to doing it right.
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

You run a company and youâ€™ve doing well. Now you want to take some money out of your company for yourself. Hooray! But before you rush off to do it, have a think about how you want to pay yourself, because doing it the wrong way can trigger big tax headaches. Below is a practical approach to do it correctly.


Overview at a Glance


Taking money out of your company is to be expected - how else are you going to get paid? But how you do it matters.

â€¢ If you treat it like salary â€“ itâ€™s simple but you need payroll systems.

â€¢ If you treat it like a dividend -Â  you need profit, the correct share class, and formal declaration.

â€¢ If you treat it like a loan - you need an agreement, payment terms, interest and repayment schedules. You also need to be aware of the timeline.


Why this matters


Even if you own the company, your companyâ€™s money isnâ€™t automatically your money.

Think of your company as a separate person with its own bank account. When you take money out of it, the ATO (thatâ€™s the Australian Taxation Office) wants to know why - is it:

â€¢ a wage or salary

â€¢ a dividend (profit distribution)

â€¢ a loan youâ€™ll pay back later?

If you just transfer money out without recording what itâ€™s for, the ATO will probably assume youâ€™ve taken company profits for yourself - like paying yourself a bonus - and theyâ€™ll tax you on it.


A quick look at tax credits


Before we talk about how you pay yourself from a company, it helps to understand how tax credits work in Australiaâ€”especially franking system and Division 7A, which is a set of rules designed to stop company owners from taking money out of the business tax-free.

A company pays tax at the 25% corporate tax rate. But when those profits are later paid to you as a shareholder, theyâ€™re treated as dividends and taxed at your personal tax rate (which can be as high as 45% plus medicare levy 2%).

This is where the franking system comes in.


What is the franking system?


Australia uses a system called imputation, which simply means this:
the ATO doesnâ€™t want company profits to be taxed twiceâ€”once in the companyâ€™s hands and again in yours.

So if a company has already paid tax on its profits, it can pass that tax on to shareholders as franking credits.
When you receive a franked dividend, you also receive those credits, which you may use to reduce your own tax bill.

If you receive an unfranked dividend, it means the company hasnâ€™t paid tax on that profit. In that case, you pay tax on the full amount at your personal marginal rate.


Why this matters


If you take money out of your company the wrong way, the ATO can treat it as a â€œdeemed dividendâ€ under Div7A rules. Typically they donâ€™t come with franking credits - so they end up being fully taxable.

This means:

â€¢ The money you take from your company will be added to your personal income, and

â€¢ You may end up paying more tax than if it had been set up properly.


What are your main options for putting money in your pocket?


Below are the three common ways to take money out - with easy pros and cons.


Option 1 - Pay yourself a salary or wage (through payroll/STP)


Pros

â€¢ Straightforward: youâ€™re treated like an employee.

â€¢ Tax is withheld and reported automatically via STP/BAS.

â€¢ Superannuation (SG) is handled as part of payroll.

â€¢ Great for stable, regular income.

Cons

â€¢ You need STP-enabled payroll software.

â€¢ The company must withhold PAYG tax and pay super.

â€¢ Ongoing admin (or outsource to your accountant).

Best for when:

youâ€™re working in the business and want regular pay, or

the company can manage ongoing payroll and super payments.


Option 2 - Declare a dividend (shareholder distribution)


Pros

â€¢ If the company has paid tax, dividends can carry franking credits to reduce your personal tax.

â€¢ Good for one-off profit distributions.

â€¢ Useful when your company has accumulated franking credits you want to use.

Cons

â€¢ You need distributable profits to pay dividends.

â€¢ You must treat all shareholders of the same share class equally.

â€¢ Requires documentation (dividend statements, minutes) and correct tax reporting.

Best for when:

The company has clear profits and you want to share those profits with shareholders rather than create a loan.

The company has unused franking credits and you want to avoid extra tax on money the company already paid tax on.

An example: you issued yourself $10,000 dividend

If the company already paid $2,500 tax on the profit, you receive a $10,000 dividend with a $2,500 franking credit. You declare $12,500 income but subtract the $2,500 credit from your personal tax bill - preventing double taxation.

âš ï¸Tax Warning!

Franking credit deficit

If the company gives out too many franking credits, it may need to pay extra tax to top up the franking account.

Franking credit trap

If the corporate tax rate falls (e.g., 27.5% â†’ 25%), some credits from earlier years may become â€œstuckâ€ because you may only frank dividends at the current lower rate.

Planning ahead helps avoid accidentally wasting credits.

To manage this, consider:

â€¢ Paying dividends earlier (before a rate drop takes effect) to use up higher-rate credits.

â€¢ Also, review your personal tax position â€” if youâ€™re on a lower marginal tax rate, you may receive a refund of franking credits. If your personal tax rate is high, you may prefer that the company retain profits until it can pay fully franked dividends at the higher rate OR until other strategies can unlock trapped credits.

â€¢ Looking ahead, itâ€™s worth planning for future profits to make sure trapped credits can be used later and checking your companyâ€™s base rate entity status each year, as this affects the maximum franking rate you may apply. A base rate entity is generally a company with turnover under $50 million and where no more than 80% of its income is from passive sources such as rent, interest, or dividends.

You can find more information about franking credits on the ATO website.


Option 3 - Take money as a Division 7A loan (formal director loan)


This is when the company â€œlendsâ€ you money. Itâ€™s fine â€” as long as you follow the rules.

Pros

â€¢ Immediate cashflow without payroll and PAYG withholding.

â€¢ No immediate tax if the loan is compliant.

â€¢ You get extra time before the first minimum yearly repayment (MYR).

Cons

â€¢ Requires a written loan agreement by the companyâ€™s lodgment day.

â€¢ Needs minimum yearly repayments (principal + interest).

â€¢ Interest must be charged at/above the ATO benchmark rate (8.37% for 2025â€“26).

â€¢ If you break the rules, the loan becomes a deemed unfranked dividend â€” and fully taxable.

Best for when:

â€¢ You need cash now and the company (and you) are confident you may meet the repayment schedule.

â€¢ You want to avoid payroll and super in the short term but can commit to formalising the loan and making minimum yearly repayments.

â€¢ You are okay with more documentation / formal structure, and are comfortable with the idea of it being a loan (not a â€œfree withdrawalâ€).

You can find more information about a complying Div7A loan on the ATO website.

An example: you withdraw $50,000

Imagine Save Money Pty Ltd lends its shareholder (Ben) $50,000 on 9 â€¯Mayâ€¯2022.

If Ben had simply transferred $50,000 from the company to himself without any documentation, loan agreement, or formal payroll/salary/dividend declaration and he has not repaid it back to the company, then:

The money would likely be treated by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) as an unfranked deemed dividend.

Ben would include the $50,000 in his assessable income, with no franking credits, and could end up paying tax at his individual marginal rate 45% on that amount.

If the company doesnâ€™t have a distributable surplus, this may limit the deemed dividend - but itâ€™s still risky.

Now, compare that to the complying Div7A loan route:

Save Money Pty Ltd and Ben set up a Divisionâ€¯7A complying loan agreement before the company lodges its tax return for the year ended 30â€¯Juneâ€¯2023. The loan follows the required rules: for example, it is unsecured, has a 7â€‘year term, and charges interest at the ATO benchmark rate.

Hereâ€™s what happens next:

Company side:

Each year, the company records the interest Ben pays as income.

That interest is taxed at the companyâ€™s rate.

Benâ€™s side:

Ben must make minimum yearly repayments (MYRs) â€” covering both principal and interest â€” by 30â€¯June each year until the loan is fully repaid.

If all MYRs are made, the loan avoids being treated as a deemed dividend.

Whether Ben can deduct the interest depends on how he uses the money (usually deductible if used for income-producing purposes).

Must plan ahead because payments are due every 30â€¯June while the loan is outstanding.

Ben can choose to repay the loan faster than 7 years if he wants.

Ben can make/offset the MYRs by declaring normal dividends with franking credits and wages to himself.

Ben gets the cash immediately but does not pay â€˜taxâ€™ on the loan itself right away. Tax is deferred until the company earns interest or if the loan is later converted into a dividend or salary.

*Exact repayments for later years cannot be finalised until the ATO publishes benchmark rates for those years.

âš ï¸Tax Warning! Section 109R â€” â€œRepay and redrawâ€ trap

If you repay a loan just before 30 June but take the money out again straight after, the ATO can ignore the repayment and still treat the loan as unpaid. This can trigger a deemed dividend.

For example, Ben withdraws $50,000 from Save Money Pty Ltd and puts it in his personal home loan offset account to reduce interest throughout the year. Right before 30â€¯June, he transfers the $50,000 back to the company to â€œrepayâ€ his Divisionâ€¯7A loan, only to withdraw the same amount again immediately after year-end.

At first glance, it looks like he made the repayment, but under Sectionâ€¯109R, the ATO can disregard this repayment because it was not a genuine repayment. The loan remains outstanding, and a deemed unfranked dividend may arise, creating an unexpected tax liability.


Tips for Making a Divisionâ€¯7A Loan Complying


Have a Written Loan Agreement:Â Include loan amount, interest rate (ATO benchmark or higher), terms.

Make Minimum Yearly Repayments (MYRs): Pay principal + interest annually by 30â€¯June. Missing payments can trigger a deemed dividend. Use the ATO Divisionâ€¯7A calculator to work out the correct MYR.

Plan Ahead & Ensure Cashflow: Make sure you may meet repayments each year. Consider both your personal finances and the companyâ€™s needs to avoid surprises.

Avoid Repay & Redraw Schemes: Donâ€™t repay and immediately borrow the same funds again â€” the ATO can disregard this under Sectionâ€¯109R.


Check-list for year-end cleanup


As you approach the end of the financial year (30 June), go through this:

â€¢ Whatâ€™s the outstanding director loan balance?

â€¢ Can you pay yourself a salary or bonus this year?

â€¢ Do you have enough profit to declare a dividend?

â€¢ Does your company have unused franking credits?

â€¢ Do all shareholders hold the same class of shares?

â€¢ If youâ€™re doing a loanâ€”do you have the written agreement in place and are the yearly repayments happening?

â€¢ Make a decision before the company lodges its tax return to avoid surprises.

Got questions? Reach out to us via app chat. You can also find more info about Div7A loan on this ATO website.

<< Back to +Taxes

Best for when:

The company has clear profits and you want to share those profits with shareholders rather than create a loan.

The company has unused franking credits and you want to avoid extra tax on money the company already paid tax on.

An example: you issued yourself $10,000 dividend

If the company already paid $2,500 tax on the profit, you receive a $10,000 dividend with a $2,500 franking credit. You declare $12,500 income but subtract the $2,500 credit from your personal tax bill - preventing double taxation.

âš ï¸Tax Warning!

Franking credit deficit

If the company gives out too many franking credits, it may need to pay extra tax to top up the franking account.

Franking credit trap

If the corporate tax rate falls (e.g., 27.5% â†’ 25%), some credits from earlier years may become â€œstuckâ€ because you can only frank dividends at the current lower rate.

Planning ahead helps avoid accidentally wasting credits.

To manage this, consider:

â€¢ Paying dividends earlier (before a rate drop takes effect) to use up higher-rate credits.

â€¢ Also, review your personal tax position â€” if youâ€™re on a lower marginal tax rate, you may receive a refund of franking credits. If your personal tax rate is high, you may prefer that the company retain profits until it can pay fully franked dividends at the higher rate OR until other strategies can unlock trapped credits.

â€¢ Looking ahead, itâ€™s worth planning for future profits to make sure trapped credits can be used later and checking your companyâ€™s base rate entity status each year, as this affects the maximum franking rate you can apply. A base rate entity is generally a company with turnover under $50 million and where no more than 80% of its income is from passive sources such as rent, interest, or dividends.

You can find more information about franking credits on the ATO website.


Option 3 - Take money as a Division 7A loan (formal director loan)


This is when the company â€œlendsâ€ you money. Itâ€™s fine â€” as long as you follow the rules.

Pros

â€¢ Immediate cashflow without payroll and PAYG withholding.

â€¢ No immediate tax if the loan is compliant.

â€¢ You get extra time before the first minimum yearly repayment (MYR).

Cons

â€¢ Requires a written loan agreement by the companyâ€™s lodgment day.

â€¢ Needs minimum yearly repayments (principal + interest).

â€¢ Interest must be charged at/above the ATO benchmark rate (8.37% for 2025â€“26).

â€¢ If you break the rules, the loan becomes a deemed unfranked dividend â€” and fully taxable.

Best for when:

â€¢ You need cash now and the company (and you) are confident you can meet the repayment schedule.

â€¢ You want to avoid payroll and super in the short term but can commit to formalising the loan and making minimum yearly repayments.

â€¢ You are okay with more documentation / formal structure, and are comfortable with the idea of it being a loan (not a â€œfree withdrawalâ€).

You can find more information about a complying Div7A loan on the ATO website.

An example: you withdraw $50,000

Imagine Save Money Pty Ltd lends its shareholder (Ben) $50,000 on 9 â€¯Mayâ€¯2022.

If Ben had simply transferred $50,000 from the company to himself without any documentation, loan agreement, or formal payroll/salary/dividend declaration and he has not repaid it back to the company, then:

The money would likely be treated by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) as an unfranked deemed dividend.

Ben would include the $50,000 in his assessable income, with no franking credits, and could end up paying tax at his individual marginal rate 45% on that amount.

If the company doesnâ€™t have a distributable surplus, this may limit the deemed dividend - but itâ€™s still risky.

Now, compare that to the complying Div7A loan route:

Save Money Pty Ltd and Ben set up a Divisionâ€¯7A complying loan agreement before the company lodges its tax return for the year ended 30â€¯Juneâ€¯2023. The loan follows the required rules: for example, it is unsecured, has a 7â€‘year term, and charges interest at the ATO benchmark rate.

Hereâ€™s what happens next:

Company side:

Each year, the company records the interest Ben pays as income.

That interest is taxed at the companyâ€™s rate.

Benâ€™s side:

Ben must make minimum yearly repayments (MYRs) â€” covering both principal and interest â€” by 30â€¯June each year until the loan is fully repaid.

If all MYRs are made, the loan avoids being treated as a deemed dividend.

Whether Ben can deduct the interest depends on how he uses the money (usually deductible if used for income-producing purposes).

Must plan ahead because payments are due every 30â€¯June while the loan is outstanding.

Ben can choose to repay the loan faster than 7 years if he wants.

Ben can make/offset the MYRs by declaring normal dividends with franking credits and wages to himself.

Ben gets the cash immediately but does not pay â€˜taxâ€™ on the loan itself right away. Tax is deferred until the company earns interest or if the loan is later converted into a dividend or salary.

*Exact repayments for later years cannot be finalised until the ATO publishes benchmark rates for those years.

âš ï¸Tax Warning! Section 109R â€” â€œRepay and redrawâ€ trap

If you repay a loan just before 30 June but take the money out again straight after, the ATO can ignore the repayment and still treat the loan as unpaid. This can trigger a deemed dividend.

For example, Ben withdraws $50,000 from Save Money Pty Ltd and puts it in his personal home loan offset account to reduce interest throughout the year. Right before 30â€¯June, he transfers the $50,000 back to the company to â€œrepayâ€ his Divisionâ€¯7A loan, only to withdraw the same amount again immediately after year-end.

At first glance, it looks like he made the repayment, but under Sectionâ€¯109R, the ATO can disregard this repayment because it was not a genuine repayment. The loan remains outstanding, and a deemed unfranked dividend may arise, creating an unexpected tax liability.


Tips for Making a Divisionâ€¯7A Loan Complying


Have a Written Loan Agreement:Â Include loan amount, interest rate (ATO benchmark or higher), terms.

Make Minimum Yearly Repayments (MYRs): Pay principal + interest annually by 30â€¯June. Missing payments can trigger a deemed dividend. Use the ATO Divisionâ€¯7A calculator to work out the correct MYR.

Plan Ahead & Ensure Cashflow: Make sure you can meet repayments each year. Consider both your personal finances and the companyâ€™s needs to avoid surprises.

Avoid Repay & Redraw Schemes: Donâ€™t repay and immediately borrow the same funds again â€” the ATO can disregard this under Sectionâ€¯109R.


Check-list for year-end cleanup


As you approach the end of the financial year (30 June), go through this:

â€¢ Whatâ€™s the outstanding director loan balance?

â€¢ Can you pay yourself a salary or bonus this year?

â€¢ Do you have enough profit to declare a dividend?

â€¢ Does your company have unused franking credits?

â€¢ Do all shareholders hold the same class of shares?

â€¢ If youâ€™re doing a loanâ€”do you have the written agreement in place and are the yearly repayments happening?

â€¢ Make a decision before the company lodges its tax return to avoid surprises.

Got questions? Reach out to us via app chat. You can also find more info about Div7A loan on this ATO website.

title: Sole Trader or Company? How to Choose the Right Structure
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: Starting a business can be exciting but confusing. in this article explains the key differences between a sole trader and a company in simple terms, so you may choose the right structure for your goals.
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

Starting a business is exciting, but structure decisions can be tricky. This article explains the key differences between a sole trader and a company in plain English, so you may choose the right structure for your goals.

Starting a business in Australia? One of the biggest decisions youâ€™ll make early on is how to set it up. Should you keep things simple and go it alone as a sole trader, or register a company and give your business its own legal life?

Both options can work perfectly - it really depends on your goals, how much youâ€™re earning, and how much risk youâ€™re willing to take. Get it right from the start, and youâ€™ll save yourself a lot of time, stress, and tax surprises later on.

Letâ€™s break it down in plain English.


Whatâ€™s a Sole Trader?


Being a sole trader means itâ€™s just you - you run the show, keep the profits, and make all the decisions. Itâ€™s quick and affordable to set up, and perfect for freelancers, small side hustles, or anyone testing a business idea.

The flip side? You and the business are legally the same. So if your business owes money or gets into trouble, your personal assets (like your home or car) could be on the line. Youâ€™ll also report all business income and expenses on your personal tax return.

Best for:

â€¢ Solo operators and freelancers

â€¢ Low-cost, low-risk businesses

â€¢ Anyone starting out or testing an idea


Whatâ€™s a Company?


A company is a separate legal entity. Itâ€™s like a totally different person in the eyes of the law. It has its own ABN, ACN, and TFN. That means it can earn money, own assets, sign contracts, and take on debts in its own name.

You (and any co-owners) become shareholders, and the company directors make the day-to-day decisions. The company files its own tax return and pays tax at the company rate â€” 25% for small businesses in 2025.

Because itâ€™s separate, your personal liability is limited â€” so your house and savings are generally protected if something goes wrong.

Best for:

â€¢ Businesses planning to grow or hire staff

â€¢ Those wanting to attract investors or raise capital

â€¢ Companies holding valuable assets or operating in higher-risk industries


When Does It Make Sense to Switch from Sole Trader to Company?


A lot of small businesses start out as sole traders - itâ€™s simple, flexible, easy to run. But as profits grow, a company structure often makes more sense.

You might think about switching if:

â€¢ Your taxable income consistently hits $130kâ€“$150k+

â€¢ You want to protect your personal assets

â€¢ You plan to reinvest profits or bring in investors

â€¢ Youâ€™re hiring more employees or moving into a higher-risk industry


Meet Emma â€“ A Real Life Example


Emma runs a catering business in Sydney.

As a sole trader:

â€¢ She earned about $140,000 profit in the 2025 financial year

â€¢ Paid tax at her personal rate (37% + Medicare levy)

â€¢ Worked mostly with contractors

â€¢ Kept things simple with GST on a cash basis

As her business grew, so did her profits (and her tax bill). She realised she could keep more of her earnings if her business paid the 25% company tax rate instead of her personal rate. She also wanted to hire permanent staff and protect her personal assets.

So, she made the switch.

*Rounded, simplified figures for example purposes

By forming a company, Emma could reinvest more of her profit, hire employees, and build credibility with clients and investors.


What Actually Changes When You Form a Company


â€¢ New business identity: Register with ANNA to get your company ABN, ACN, TFN, and business account in one go.

â€¢ Hiring more staff: Run payroll, make PAYG payments, report GST and PAYGW in your BAS.

â€¢ Company tax: Lodge a company tax return and pay 25% tax on profits.

â€¢ Paying yourself: Take money out as wages (taxed as salary) or dividends (with franking credits).

â€¢ Asset protection: Your personal assets are safer â€” though directors still have some responsibilities.

â€¢ Growth & investment: Easier to raise capital and attract investors.

â€¢ Branding boost: â€œPty Ltdâ€ adds credibility to your business name.


What About Transferring Assets (like a Car)?


Emmaâ€™s car is a depreciating asset, so it loses value over time. When she moves it from her sole trader business into her company, it triggers a 'balancing adjustment event'. In simple terms, any gain or loss from the car affects her personal taxable income.

That means any gain or loss may affect her personal taxable income - but thereâ€™s a possible small business restructure rollover (Subdivisionâ€¯328â€‘G) that can help her avoid immediate tax, if she meet certain conditions.

In practice, most business cars lose value, so any gain or loss is usually small, and rollovers rarely provide a significant tax benefit.

Emma will also need to transfer the registration and pay stamp duty, so the company becomes the legal owner.


Before You Decide â€“ Ask Yourself


â€¢ How much profit do I expect in the next few years?

â€¢ How much risk am I comfortable taking personally?

â€¢ Will I reinvest profits or distribute them?

â€¢ Am I planning to hire employees or attract investors?

â€¢ Do I need asset protection or extra credibility?

â€¢ Am I okay with more paperwork for better long-term benefits?

A Quick Note on Personal Services Income (PSI)

If most of your income comes from your personal skills or labour - like consulting or freelancing - PSI rules might apply. They can affect how you claim deductions and whether income-splitting through a company is allowed. Weâ€™ve got a separate blog explaining PSI in plain English.


The Bottom Line


Sole trader: simple, flexible, and low-cost - great for starting out.
Company: structured, protective, and scalable - great for growing.

Many Australian businesses begin as sole traders and move to a company when itâ€™s time to level up.

Key takeaway: Pick the structure that fits your goals, income, and comfort with risk. And before you lock it in, have a quick chat with your accountant - or with us at ANNA Money - to make sure youâ€™re set up the smart way.

Got questions? Reach out to us via app chat. You can also find more info about business structure on this website.

<< Back to +Taxes
