title: EOFY Survival Guide for Australian Small Businesses
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: EOFY can be straightforward with the right process. Our survival guide is designed to help Aussie small businesseses/companies tackle tax, BAS, and compliance without the headache, so you may wrap things up with confidence
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

EOFY doesnâ€™t have to be scary. Our survival guide helps Aussie small businesses/companies tackle tax, BAS, and compliance without the headache, so you may wrap things up with confidence


Overview at a Glance


â€¢ Always keep your books tidy: Keep financial records and bank reconciliations up to date

â€¢ Start early: May is the ideal time to start planning for tax and collating key documents

â€¢ Finalise payroll: Complete STP reporting and ensure all employee entitlements are paid on time

â€¢ Year-end adjustments: Post all adjusting journals to finalise your accounts for the financial year

â€¢ Lodge and pay on time: Review your business tax obligations to stay compliant


Why EOFY Matters for Small Companies


For directors and owners of Australian small proprietary companies, End of Financial Year (EOFY) is more than just lodging a tax return. Itâ€™s your annual opportunity to assess your business health, plan for cash flow and tax savings, and make sure youâ€™re compliant with the ATO, ASIC, and other regulators. Yes, itâ€™s a series of obligations, but itâ€™s also a good time to take a snapshot of your company and make sure everything is heading in the right direction.Â So with that in mind, hereâ€™s your comprehensive guide to getting your businessÂ  EOFY-ready.


When is EOFY?


For most small businesses in Australia, the financial year ends on 30 June each year. Each financial year covers the period from 1 July to 30 June.


Why start early in May?


As with most things in life, itâ€™s not a good idea to leave your EOFY to the last minute.Â 
May is the perfect time for small business owners to get ahead of EOFY. Starting early gives you time to organise records, identify deductions, review cash flow, and make strategic decisions before 30 June, without a panicky scramble before the deadline.
Accounts get busy! From March onwards, accountants enter the most hectic period, finalising prior-year lodgements, making it harder to get their time and attention - and if you wait until they contact you, you risk missing opportunities for tax savings, cash flow planning, and stress-free compliance.


Get your records in order


Before the admin piles up, take some time to get organised. Key tasks for small business owners include:

â€¢ Reconciling all business bank accounts, credit cards, loans, and petty cash

â€¢ Making sure income and expenses are correctly categorised and recorded

â€¢ Collating all your records for tax-sensitive items. These include:

â€¢ Legal feesHome office expensesAsset purchases or improvementsLoan agreements and repayment schedulesMaterial business expenses

â€¢ Verifying your accounts receivable (thatâ€™s money owed to you) and accounts payable (money you owe)

â€¢ Reviewing yourÂ  insurance policies

â€¢ Checking that your ATO and ASIC obligations are up to date, including:

â€¢ Outstanding BAS/IAS, income tax, FBT, PAYG instalmentsOutstanding super paymentsOutstanding ASIC fees

â€¢ Renewing business name registrations

â€¢ Reviewing company details, and storing constitution and governance documents

With ANNA Money +Taxes, you may upload and attach evidence directly to your transactions, automating your bookkeeping all year round, making EOFY preparation easy and hassle-free. Your taxes are much simpler if you keep on top of them throughout the year, rather than leaving them until the paperwork has mounted up.


Planning before 30 June


Good planning before EOFY can help reduce your tax liability (thatâ€™s how much tax you owe) and improve your cash flow. By reviewing your business activities and financial position early, you may take advantage of available concessions, maximise the deductions, and set yourself up for a smoother year ahead.

Have a think about these strategies before 30 June:

â€¢ Do a stocktake and write off obsolete or slow-moving inventory

â€¢ Write off any bad debts

â€¢ Delay issuing invoices if it benefits your tax position (deferring income to next year)

â€¢ Review and apply small business tax concessions

â€¢ Prepay expenses such as superannuation, rent, insurance, and subscriptions

â€¢ Take advantage of the instant asset write-off for eligible assets purchased and installed by 30 June

â€¢ Prepare budgets and forecast your tax position to plan cash flow and payments

â€¢ Review Director Loan balances and Division 7A risks

â€¢ Evaluate your business structure and ask for advice if you need it

â€¢ Set aside money for income tax, June BAS, super, and other tax obligations

â€¢ Ask for Quantity Surveyors (depreciation report) for business premises refurbishment if applicable

â€¢ Talk to experts if youâ€™re unsure of anything


Actions after 30 June


Once the financial year closes, finalise all pending tasks to make sure youâ€™re compliant and a have a smooth, straightforward transition into the new year. You should also:

â€¢ Collect together all your year-end documents, including:

â€¢ Bank and credit card statementsYear-end tax summaries for investmentsLoan statements with updated balances

â€¢ Finalise payroll processing and lodge STP reports by 14 July

â€¢ Lodge and pay the June BAS and super by 28 July

â€¢ Record year-end adjustments, including but not limited to:

â€¢ Division 7A prepayments, accruals, provisionsTrading stock adjustmentsDepreciation and amortisationHire purchase adjustmentsAdjusting entries due to prior-year timing difference

â€¢ Review major sales and purchases

â€¢ Prepare a Profit & Loss statement and compare results with last year

â€¢ Reconcile Balance Sheet items and make sure supporting documents are on file

â€¢ Reconcile ATO tax liabilities, including GST, PAYGW, and income tax

â€¢ Review Director Loan accounts

â€¢ Assess available tax incentives and eligibility, such as:

â€¢ Prior year lossesAvailable franking creditsInstant asset write-offR&D tax incentivesCapital gains/lossesEntertainment and donationsLate super paymentsBad debtsFines and penaltiesCapital expenses

â€¢ Know your due dates and lodge your company income tax return, taxable payments annual report (TPAR) for certain industries

â€¢ Finalise budgets, cash flow forecasts, and business plans for the new financial year


Final thoughts


As you may imagine, EOFY can feel overwhelming - but with the right preparation, it becomes an opportunity, not a headache. By starting early, staying organised, and making informed financial decisions, you may maximise your tax savings, keep your business compliant, and set yourself up for a stronger year ahead. Whether you prefer to DIY or let technology handle the heavy lifting, tools like ANNAâ€™s +Taxes can take the stress out of EOFY and help your business run smoothly all year round. Because you started a business to grow, not to do your taxes!

title: ACN vs ABN vs TFN: What Each One Means
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: Starting a business in Australia? Youâ€™ve probably heard these three sets ofÂ  letters thrown around: ACN, ABN, TFN. They might sound similar, but each has a different purpose. in this article will help you understand what they are, who issues them, whether you need them, and how they differ
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

Starting a business in Australia? Youâ€™ve probably heard these three sets ofÂ  letters thrown around: ACN, ABN, TFN. They might sound similar, but each has a different purpose. This article will help you understand what they are, who issues them, whether you need them, and how they differ


Overview at a Glance



Whatâ€™s an ACN?


ACN stands for Australian Company Number. Itâ€™s a unique 9-digit unique number issued to every company registered in Australia.


Who issues it?


The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) issues ACNs when a company is registered.


Whatâ€™s it for?


Identifies your company on the ASIC register.

Used on official company documents and legal paperwork.

Helps distinguish your company from others with similar names.


Do you need it?


Only if you are registering a company. Sole traders, trusts and partnerships donâ€™t get an ACN.

Example:

ACN: 123 456 789

Think of ACN as your companyâ€™s â€œID cardâ€ with ASIC.


What is an ABN?


ABN stands for Australian Business Number. Itâ€™s a unique 11-digit number used for business dealings with the government and other businesses.


Who issues it?


The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) issues ABNs through the business registration process.


Whatâ€™s it for?


Identifies your business for tax purposes.

Allows you to register for GST, PAYG withholding, and other business taxes.

Needed for invoicing, claiming GST credits, and dealing with other businesses.


Do you need it?


Yes, if youâ€™re running a business, regardless of the structure - a sole trader, partnership, company, or trust - you need an ABN.

Example:

ABN: 12 345 678 901

ABN is like your business â€œpassportâ€ for dealing with other businesses and the government.


What is a TFN?


TFN stands for Tax File Number. It is a unique 9-digit number issued to individuals, companies, partnerships, trusts, and superannuation funds for tax purposes.


Who issues it?


The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) issues ABNs through the business registration process.


Whatâ€™s it for?


Used for income tax and other tax reporting.

You need it to open bank accounts, apply for government benefits, and lodge tax returns.


Do you need it?


Yes. Every person and entity earning income or operating a business in Australia must have a TFN.

Example:

TFN: 123 456 789

TFN is your personal or business â€œtax ID.â€

title: Company Income Tax in Australia: Quick Start Guide
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: A simple guide to company income tax in Australia. Learn tax rates, lodgement rules, and key tips to manage your business tax obligations effectively
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

A practical primer on company income tax in Australia. Learn tax rates, lodgement rules, and key tips to manage your business tax obligations effectively


Overview at a Glance:


â€¢ Company tax rate: 25% on net profits for most small company businesses

â€¢ Company Income Tax due dates: The due date may vary. Generally, 28 Feb (self-prepared with no pass return outstanding) or up to 15 May with a tax agent

â€¢ How to lodge: Submit your company income tax return via a SBR-enabled software, or through your accountant

â€¢ Penalties: Late tax returns can mean fines from $330 plus daily compounding interest


What is Company Income Tax?


Itâ€™s the tax your company pays on its business profits - that means the total income minus your business expenses. For the 2025 financial year (1 July 2025 to 30 June 2026), the Company Income Tax rate is 25% for small businesses.Â 

Every company in Australia needs to lodge a Company Income Tax Return once a year.


What goes in a Company Income Tax Return?


Here are the key things youâ€™ll need to include in your Company Income Tax Return:

â€¢ Total income: Such as sales, services, and any other money coming in

â€¢ Business expenses: Such as rent, wages, subscriptions, the usual suspects

â€¢ Any losses from previous years: Sometimes previous losses can be used to offset the profit your business has made in current period profit. So include any previous tax losses, they may help you reduce the tax youâ€™ll have to pay

â€¢ Tax instalments already paid: Tax instalments are pre-paid taxes that ATO may need in certain circumstances. When youâ€™re filling in your final year end assessment, make sure to include the taxes youâ€™ve already paid so youâ€™re not taxed twice

Need a clearer picture? See a sample return for FY 2025.


When is Company Income Tax due?


Generally, the lodgement and payment date for small companies is 28 February if you lodge it yourself, rather than using a tax agent. If you have any previous year returns still outstanding, the due date will be 31 October. If youâ€™re using a tax agent or ask for a deferral, you might get a bit more time to file your Return.

Stressed about deadlines? Your ANNA tax calendarâ€™s got your back with deadline reminders tailored just for you.


Quick Tips:


â€¢ Keep it Cleanâ€¨No cents. No rounding up. Whole dollars only on Income Tax.

â€¢ Nothing to Report?â€¨Just lodge a NIL Income Tax Return through ANNA.

â€¢ Oops! Made a mistake?â€¨Lodge a Company Income Tax Amendment to fix the error. However, you may incur interest and penalties if the amendment increases the money you owe.

â€¢ Stay on top of itâ€¨Keep solid records of sales and expenses. ANNA can help you by sorting and categorising your records, matching your transactions and keeping track of your uploaded evidence. So your return will be neat and tidy, and you may claim everything youâ€™re entitled to.

â€¢ Stash that tax cashâ€¨Set aside estimated tax as you go - your future self will thank you. Use ANNA pots (coming soon) and real time tax estimation (also coming soon) to automatically put money aside for tax payments.

Got questions? Reach out to us in the app chat. You can also find more info about Income Tax on the ATO website.

title: GST and BAS in Australia: Simple Beginner Guide
author: Livia Lin
excerpt: Understand GST and BAS in Australia with this practical guide. Learn how GST works, when to register, and how to lodge BAS to stay compliant with the ATO
excerpt_zh: é€šè¿‡æœ¬å¿«é€ŸæŒ‡å—äº†è§£æ¾³å¤§åˆ©äºšçš„ GST å’Œ BASã€‚äº†è§£ GST å¦‚ä½•è¿ä½œã€ä½•æ—¶æ³¨å†Œä»¥åŠå¦‚ä½•æäº¤ BAS ä»¥éµå®ˆ ATO
content_text:
Editor note: The following article has been adapted for Flexpath readers while preserving the same technical meaning.

Understand GST and BAS in Australia with this practical overview. Learn how GST works, when to register, and how to lodge BAS to stay compliant with the ATO


Overview at a Glance:


â€¢ GST registration: Required if your annual GST turnover is $75,000 or more

â€¢ BAS due dates: Most small businesses lodge BAS quarterly, due 28 Oct, 28 Feb, 28 Apr, 28 Jul

â€¢ How to lodge: Submit your BAS online, via your ATO online services, a SBR-enabled software, or through your accountant

â€¢ Penalties: Late BAS lodgement can mean fines from $330 plus daily compounding interest


What is GST?


GST (Goods and Services Tax) is a 10% tax on most goods and services sold in Australia. If you're registered for GST, you're expected to charge it on sales, pay it to the ATO, and claim back the GST on your eligible business purchases.


Who needs to register for GST?


If your GST turnover hits $75,000 or more, youâ€™ve got 21 days to register. In some cases, youâ€™ll need to register no matter what you earn, like if youâ€™re driving for Uber or doing other ride-share gigs. Earning less? You can still register voluntarily if it makes sense for your business. Got questions? Reach out to us in the app chat. ANNA can help you get registered.


What is a BAS?


A Business Activity Statement (BAS) is your regular tax check-in with the ATO. Itâ€™s where you report and pay GST, PAYG withholding (tax on wages), PAYG instalments (prepaid tax), and other business taxes. Most small businesses lodge it quarterly. See a sample.


Whatâ€™s an IAS?


An Instalment Activity Statement (IAS) is like a mini BAS. Itâ€™s used to report and pay things like PAYG instalments or withholding tax. Youâ€™ll usually get one monthly from the ATO if you should lodge it. See a sample.


So, whatâ€™s the difference between BAS and IAS?


Both are ATO forms used to report and pay business taxes but they serve different setups:

BAS is the full kit: GST, PAYG withholding, PAYG instalments, and more
IAS is the smaller version: no GST, just PAYG obligations.

Example Time:
Letâ€™s say your business is registered for GST and lodges BAS quarterly. Youâ€™ve also got employees, so youâ€™re withholding PAYG tax from their wages. If your payroll hits a certain threshold, the ATO might ask you to report PAYG withholding monthly, even if everything else stays quarterly. In that case, youâ€™ll lodge a quarterly BAS for GST and PAYG instalments, and a monthly IAS just to handle PAYG withholding for your team.

Still Confused? Check out â€˜Simpler BASâ€™
If your GST turnover is under $10 million, you only need to report 3 things under the â€œSimpler BASâ€ method:
 G1 â€“ Total Sales
 1A â€“ GST on Sales
 1B â€“ GST on Purchases


Great, so when is BAS due?


If you're on quarterly BAS, your due dates are below:

On monthly BAS? Pop into the app chat and give us a wave, we'll help you out.

Bonus: Lodging online? You could get up to 2 extra weeks, except for Q2 (1 Oct to 31 Dec), as the due date of 28 Feb already includes a Christmas extension.

Note: Due dates apply to both lodgement and payment. Stressed about remembering the dated? Your ANNA tax calendar has deadline reminders tailored just for you.


Quick Tips:


â€¢ Keep it Clean: No cents. No rounding up. Whole dollars only on IAS/BAS.

â€¢ Nothing to Report? Just lodge a NIL IAS/BAS through ANNA.

â€¢ Oops! Made a mistake? Fix it in your next BAS or lodge a revision. Use code 1A/1B to correct GST on sales/purchases.

â€¢ PAYG Instalment got you panicking? Too high? Just vary it (code T9, reason code T4). Overpaid last time? Claim a credit on B5.
Heads up: If your instalments are too low, the ATO may charge interest.

â€¢ Stay on top of it: Keep solid records of sales and expenses. ANNA can help you by matching your transactions and keeping track of your uploaded evidence. You can also use ANNA to prepare your BAS.

â€¢ Stash that GST cash: Set aside GST as you go, your future self will thank you. Use ANNA pots (coming soon) and real time GST estimator (also coming soo) to automatically put money aside for GST payments.

Got questions? Reach out to us in the app chat. You can also find more info about GST/BAS on the ATO website.
